article.title: Wide Binaries in Tycho-Gaia II: Metallicities, Abundances, and Prospects for Chemical Tagging

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of stars are primarily represented in the RAVE and LAMOST samples of wide binaries shown in the color-magnitude diagram?
Compared to the sample from Desidera et al. (2004, 2006), how does the sample of wide binaries presented in this paper differ in terms of log g and Teff?
choices: The new sample is smaller and covers a narrower range of log g and Teff.
The new sample is larger and covers a narrower range of log g and Teff.
The new sample is smaller and covers a wider range of log g and Teff.
The new sample is larger and covers a wider range of log g and Teff.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary difference between the distribution of metallicity differences (Δ[Fe/H]) in the LAMOST sample compared to the RAVE sample?
choices: The LAMOST sample shows a tighter distribution centered around Δ[Fe/H] = 0.
The LAMOST sample shows a wider distribution with more outliers.
The LAMOST sample shows a bimodal distribution.
The LAMOST sample shows no clear pattern in the distribution.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is a key advantage of using wide binaries for chemical tagging compared to using open clusters?
choices: Wide binaries are typically younger than open clusters.
Wide binaries are less contaminated by field stars.
Wide binaries have a wider range of metallicities.
Wide binaries have more precise abundance measurements.
